channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Amid Air Raid Sirens, Biden Makes Surprise Ukraine Visit
item.description: Arriving by train to Kyiv, President Biden announced more military aid for Ukraine and met with President Volodymyr Zelensky. It was a dramatic show of U.S. support days before the anniversary of Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: A Married Couple Shared a Trench on Ukraine’s Frontline. They Died in It Together.
item.description: Taras and Olha Melster signed up to help the war effort. Like many other urban professionals in Ukraine, they never expected to be sent to the front line.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivor Prickett
item.media:description: Yurii Melster visiting the graves of his son, Taras, and daughter-in-law, Olha, in the military section of a cemetery in Kropyvnytskyi, Ukraine, in February.

item.title: Protesters Rally in Jerusalem as Israel’s Leaders Look to Rein in Judges
item.description: Two contentious bills were scheduled to come up for an initial vote in the country’s Parliament on Monday, including one that would reduce the power of the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Protesters on the streets of Jerusalem on Monday. Critics of the proposed judicial overhaul say the changes would place unchecked power in the hands of the government.

item.title: Albania’s Tirana Pyramid Becomes a Symbol of the Country’s Future
item.description: An enormous pyramid was long a reminder of a brutal regime and decades of disappointments. Now, it’s a symbol of a city aspiring to be the high-tech “Tel Aviv of the Balkans.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pyramid in Tirana, Albania, was originally built as a shrine to the country’s late communist dictator, Enver Hoxha.

item.title: One Year Into War, Putin Is Crafting the Russia He Craves
item.description: In Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion has met setback after setback. But its effect at home has been very different.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

item.title: U.S. Warnings to China on Arms Aid for Russia’s War Portend Global Rift
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken says Washington has indications that Beijing is strongly considering giving military aid to Moscow for the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China in 2018.

item.title: Despite Help for Venezuelans in South America, Many Still Head to U.S.
item.description: Colombia, with U.S. help, is providing temporary visas to Venezuelan migrants. Still, financial struggles are leading many to leave for the United States.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victor Rojas, a Venezuelan violinist, arrived in Colombia in 2018, one of the beneficiaries of a visa program that has allowed migrants access to Colombian bank accounts, health care and jobs.

item.title: British Schools Work to Combat Andrew Tate’s Views
item.description: Alarmed by an online personality’s popularity among their students, educators are mobilizing to combat the sexism he promotes.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Discussing misogyny at a workshop in January at the all-boy Merchant Taylors’ School in London.

item.title: Why Milan’s Duomo Cathedral Is Still So Adored
item.description: The care for Milan’s cathedral has been nonstop since 1386, but despite the constant need for refurbishment, the beloved landmark’s hold on the city is unbreakable.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Milan’s cathedral, or Duomo, in the center of Italy’s fashion and financial capital.

item.title: On Blinken Visit, Quake Relief Soothes U.S.-Turkey Tensions
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken pledged to keep helping Turkey recover from a devastating earthquake, but there were few hints of progress on disputes over F-16 sales and NATO.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu of Turkey in Ankara on Monday.

item.title: 6.3-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Southern Turkey
item.description: Another quake struck near a town in hard-hit Hatay Province, collapsing more buildings in a region devastated by the Feb. 6 disaster that killed more than 46,000 people across Turkey and northwestern Syria.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Residents huddled together after a new earthquake struck the hard-hit southwestern city of Antakya in Hatay Province, Turkey, on Monday.

item.title: Nicola Bulley’s Body Is Found, U.K. Police Say
item.description: The disappearance of Nicola Bulley, a 45-year-old mortgage adviser and mother of two, prompted a national debate over privacy and the treatment of missing women.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The River Wyre in Lancashire, England, where the body of Nicola Bulley was recovered on Sunday.

item.title: In Biden’s Unannounced Visit to Kyiv, a Preview of an Increasingly Direct Contest With Putin
item.description: The vastly different world views of President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will become vividly apparent in a rare split-screen moment on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at a news conference in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: With an Eye on China, Philippines Moves Closer to U.S. Interests
item.description: Driven by worry about China’s aggression, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has adopted the most muscular foreign policy approach that the Philippines has seen in close to a decade.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A monument at the boardwalk in Subic Bay, once home to the largest American military base outside of the United States, commemorates the date U.S. soldiers left the Philippines.

item.title: How Biden Thinks
item.description: On Presidents’ Day, we go inside the West Wing to explain a crucial way that Biden is different from many Democrats.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Joe Biden and the Franklin D. Roosevelt portrait over the fireplace.

item.title: China Says U.S. Is ‘Not Qualified’ to Issue Orders on Arms
item.description: Beijing is trying to preserve ties with Moscow while asserting it is a neutral observer trying only to coax Russia and Ukraine into peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tanks congregating on the road in a village near the frontline in Eastern Ukraine this month.

item.title: Biden Visits Kyiv, Ukraine’s Embattled Capital, as Air-Raid Siren Sounds
item.description: President Biden took a nearly 10-hour train ride from the border of Poland to show his administration’s “unwavering support” nearly a year into Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Monday. It was an arduous journey for Mr. Biden, who nonetheless appeared energized by the opportunity to come in person.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Winner Juan Manuel Santos Criticizes West’s Focus on Ukraine
item.description: Juan Manuel Santos, a former president of Colombia, said the Ukraine war was “sucking all the energy” away from fighting other challenges, including climate change.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juan Manuel Santos, the former president of Colombia, last August in Bogota.

item.title: Despite War, Ukrainian Dance Group Returns for the ‘America’s Got Talent’ Finale
item.description: Scattered around the globe by the conflict, the group pulled together enough performers and came up with a winning routine in five days.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Light Balance Kids, a Ukrainian youth dance group, during an episode of ‘America’s Got Talent.’

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia under President Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A patriotic mural in Moscow dedicated to victory in World War II.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: A Testy Exchange Between the U.S. and China
item.description: Also, Vladimir Putin’s war narrative takes hold in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Munich, where he and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, met in a tense diplomatic exchange.

item.title: Aging Societies
item.description: Asia’s population is shrinking faster than any other continent’s.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seniors lining up for food aid vouchers in Hong Kong. Asia is experiencing a wave of older residents who need to keep working past age 65 to make ends meet.

item.title: Blinken Says He Warned China Against Providing Arms to Russia
item.description: Josep Borrell Fontelles told international leaders meeting in Munich that Western allies’ recent decision to provide Ukraine with tanks took too long.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A funeral procession for Oleksiy Lytvynov, a Ukrainian soldier, in Boryspil near Kyiv on Sunday.

item.title: Syrian State Media Reports a Deadly Strike in Damascus
item.description: Attributed in Syria to Israel, the strike appeared to be the latest episode of a long-running conflict between Israel and Iranian proxies.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Syrian security forces members inspecting a building damaged in a missile strike on Sunday in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Kamala Harris Says Russia Committed ‘Crimes Against Humanity’ in Ukraine
item.description: The vice president warned China against providing Moscow with any kind of support during her appearance at the Munich Security Conference.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris said during the Munich Security Conference on Saturday that Russia must be held to account for its “barbaric” actions in Ukraine.

item.title: Journalist Who Investigated Navalny’s Poisoning Says He Was Banned From BAFTA
item.description: Christo Grozev, a key figure in the documentary film, “Navalny,” said he was told his presence at the BAFTA awards on Sunday would pose a security risk.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: The journalist Christo Grozev, who is on the Russian Interior Ministry’s “wanted” list, said he was “banned” from attending the British Academy Film Awards because he posed a security risk.

item.title: Blinken Has Tense Meeting With Chinese Official Amid Spy Balloon Furor
item.description: The meeting resumed diplomatic contact between Washington and Beijing that had been frozen since the U.S. shot down a Chinese spy balloon.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A high-altitude surveillance balloon was recovered this month off the coast of South Carolina.

item.title: British Police Under Fire for Exposing Nicola Bulley’s Private Troubles
item.description: A police force in England said the woman struggled with alcohol abuse, which it tied to menopause, raising questions about privacy, sexism and whether the public disclosure served any purpose.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Nicola Bulley

item.title: Christian Atsu Is Found Dead in Turkey After Earthquake
item.description: Mr. Atsu, a Ghanaian national who played for the Turkish club Hatayspor, had been among the thousands of people missing. He was 31.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: “We will not forget you, Atsu. Peace be upon you, beautiful person,” his club, Hatayspor, said in a statement on Twitter on Saturday.

item.title: North Korea Launches Intercontinental Ballistic Missile
item.description: It was the North’s first test of a long-range missile in three months, and came as the country warned of strong countermeasures against joint military drills by the United States and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A news broadcast in Seoul on North Korea’s missile test on Saturday.

item.title: Video: Kamala Harris Says Russia Committed Crimes Against Humanity in Ukraine
item.description: The vice president was among a number of Western officials projecting unity behind Kyiv at the annual Munich Security Conference before the first anniversary of Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s comments in Munich on Saturday emphasized the horrors in Ukraine in the past year, including atrocities carried out by Russian forces in places like Bucha.

item.title: Chinese Official Calls U.S. Response to Balloon ‘Absurd and Hysterical’
item.description: Wang Yi spoke at the Munich Security Conference as suspense mounted over whether he might meet on the sidelines with Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Wang Yi, China’s top foreign policy official, speaking at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday.

item.title: The Return of ‘Party Down’
item.description: A cult comedy, the series returns 13 years after it last aired. There’s still time to catch up.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Earthquake Survivors’ Desperately Hunt for Shelter
item.description: For now, the Turkish government is relying on short-term solutions to house an estimated one million who are crowding into gyms, hotels and dormitories. A cruise ship is set to arrive to house thousands.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Nimet Kirac
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian families on Thursday near makeshift tents where they took shelter after powerful earthquakes in Antakya, Turkey.

item.title: The Teacher Who Volunteered in Ukraine
item.description: When Russia invaded, recruiting officers asked no questions of the Ukrainian teacher. They handed her a rifle and 120 bullets, and assigned her to a unit expecting to fight in urban combat if the Russian Army broke into Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Peter Obi Has Energized Nigeria’s Young Voters. Will They Turn Out for Him?
item.description: The race is wide open in the presidential election in Nigeria, Africa’s most populous nation and a struggling economic powerhouse. Youth looking to evict the old guard are cheering on Peter Obi, a surprise third-party candidate.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Obi, the Labour Party presidential candidate, on his way to a rally in Lagos, Nigeria, this month.

item.title: How Climate Change Is Making Tampons (and Lots of Other Stuff) More Expensive
item.description: Cotton farmers in Texas suffered record losses amid heat and drought last year, new data shows. It’s an example of how global warming is a “secret driver of inflation.”
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A few cotton bolls leftover after the harvest in Meadow, Texas.

item.title: Biden Weaves Climate Into Economy and Regulations With Two Key Picks
item.description: The president adds climate champions Lael Brainard as his top economic adviser and Richard Revesz as his regulations chief.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lael Brainard is President Biden’s new director of the National Economic Council. As vice chair of the Federal Reserve, she became known for warning of the risks climate change poses to the financial system.

item.title: Western Leaders Pledge Support for Ukraine at Munich Security Conference
item.description: As Russia’s invasion approaches its second year with no end in sight, Ukraine’s supporters faced lingering questions at the Munich Security Conference about how long their resolve will last.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Roger Cohen, Steven Erlanger and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine opened the Munich Security Conference on Friday with a video address pleading for faster weapons deliveries.

item.title: Macron Calls for Intensified Support for Ukraine but Eyes Peace Talks
item.description: His support for Ukraine and condemnation of Russia have hardened, but France’s president still stands out among Western leaders in insisting that compromise will be needed to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France addressing the Munich Security Conference on Friday.

item.title: Militants Wage Deadly Battle in Karachi Police Headquarters
item.description: The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the assault, the latest in a string of attacks from the group that have shaken many Pakistanis’ sense of security in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: A plainclothes police officer stands by the bullet-riddled walls at the police headquarters, in Karachi, Pakistan, on Friday.

item.title: Nicaragua Strips Citizenship From Hundreds Days After Prisoner Release
item.description: The country’s increasingly authoritarian government stripped more than 300 people of their citizenship, including political prisoners recently released and sent to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: The poet Gioconda Belli is among more than 300 political opponents stripped of their citizenship.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Pursues Deal on Northern Ireland
item.description: Amid political change in Scotland, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak went to Belfast to work on a trade agreement with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak met with unionist leaders in Northern Ireland on Friday to enlist their support for an agreement with the European Union on post-Brexit trade arrangements.

item.title: Biden E.P.A. Reinstates Mercury Limits Weakened Under Trump
item.description: The moves sets the stage for the agency to issue tighter controls on mercury, a neurotoxin emitted by power plants.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:description: The reinstatement of the E.P.A.’s authority to enforce the mercury rule is one of the Biden administration’s many moves to restore and strengthen environmental rules that were erased or weakened by the Trump administration.

item.title: Images Show Hidden Clues About Iran’s Significant Fighter Jet Upgrade
item.description: In early February, Iranian state media aired a video about an underground Air Force base. Details in the footage and satellite images point toward the possible arrival of advanced Russian jets.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl and Alexander Cardia

item.title: U.S. and China Vie in Hazy Zone Where Balloons, U.F.O.s and Missiles Fly
item.description: American officials are worried China is far along in developing military technology that operates in the unregulated high-altitude zone of “near space.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. military commanders, lawmakers and policy experts say they fear China has pulled ahead of the United States in thinking strategically about how to use “near space” and in deploying assets there.

item.title: 18 Migrants Found Dead in Truck in Bulgaria
item.description: The dead appeared to have suffocated inside a secret compartment under a load of lumber.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Police officers at the site where at least 18 migrants were found dead in an abandoned truck near Sofia, Bulgaria, on Friday.

item.title: New technology, same old blind spot?
item.description: Don’t just look at what technology can do, look at what it helps people do to each other.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Microsoft’s new Bing search engine using A.I. is demonstrated to media at their campus in Redmond, Washington, in February.

item.title: Eileen Sheridan, Who Dominated Cycling in Postwar Britain, Dies at 99
item.description: Known as “the Mighty Atom,” she excelled at long-distance time trials and set several records that still stand more than 70 years later.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Eileen Sheridan in 1951. Though she was a physically gifted cyclist, she seemed driven less by competitive ambition than by the sheer joy of the ride.

item.title: South Africa begins naval drills with Russia and China, despite criticism that it implies support of the war.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The Russian military frigate Admiral Gorshkov docked in the harbor of Cape Town on Monday in advance of an 11-day joint maritime drill being staged with South Africa and China.

item.title: A Timeline of Nicola Bulley’s Disappearance
item.description: Ms. Bulley, a 45-year-old mother, was last seen on Jan. 27 outside a village in northwestern England. Her disappearance led to national headlines and rampant speculation on social media.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Nicola Bulley disappeared from a park in northwestern England late last month.

item.title: Germany’s allies pushed Germany to send tanks to Ukraine. Now, Scholz is the one urging them.
item.description: At
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz was careful on Friday not to imply that Germany would be taking a more forceful role in providing weapons to Ukraine overall.

item.title: A Russian Mole in Germany Sows Suspicions at Home, and Beyond
item.description: A director at Germany’s spy service was picked up on suspicion of passing intelligence to Russia. German officials and allies worry just how deep the problem goes.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Christopher F. Schuetze and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: The small Bavarian town of Weilheim, where a director of Germany’s spy agency lived and was arrested in December on suspicion of spying for Russia.

item.title: Ex-Worker at U.K. Embassy in Berlin Is Sentenced to 13 Years in Prison for Spying for Russia
item.description: The former security guard, who was caught in an undercover operation, had pleaded guilty to passing secret information to the Russian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Metropolitan Police Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still, from a hidden camera at the security kiosk in the British Embassy in Berlin, of David Ballantyne Smith taking video of CCTV monitors in 2021. He was a security guard at the embassy at the time.

item.title: At a security conference in Munich, Zelensky invokes the battle of David and Goliath.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: “There is no alternative but to defeat Goliath,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said.

item.title: Pandemic Closures, Unpatrolled Beach Visits Blamed for Spike in Drownings
item.description: The number of drownings nationwide last summer exceeded the 10-year average by 44 percent, while New South Wales is presently having “one of our worst summers on record.”
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Surfers enjoying the waves at Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, on Friday.
